elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">In this work, we obtained a highly rare three-dimensional Zn(II) MOF, namely [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)][(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·DMF (BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>,N<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bis(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide), and Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dimethylamine cation) by solvo(hydro)thermal method. This polymer was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry and solid-state luminescence analysis. The outstanding structural feature of it is (3, 4)-connected net with unprecedented (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology and self-penetrating motif.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this work, we obtained a highly rare three-dimensional Zn(II) MOF, namely [Zn2(BTC)2(L)][(Me2NH2)2]⋅DMF (BTC3- =1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L=N1,N4-bis(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide), and Me2NH2 =dimethylamine cation) by solvo(hydro)thermal method. This polymer was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry and solid-state luminescence analysis. The outstanding structural feature of it is (3, 4)-connected net with unprecedented (6⋅82)(6⋅85)(62 ⋅10)(62 ⋅83 ⋅10) topology and self-penetrating motif.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">We present here a new flexible, acylamide ligand to construct (3, 4)-connected net. The resultant presents a previously unobserved topology matrix featuring (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology symbol. Moreover, the self-penetrating structure and the potential porosity in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is still notable.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0040" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

We present here a new flexible, acylamide ligand to construct (3, 4)-connected net. The resultant presents a previously unobserved topology matrix featuring (6⋅82)(6⋅85)(62 ⋅10)(62 ⋅83 ⋅10) topology symbol. Moreover, the self-penetrating structure and the potential porosity in 1 is still notable.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0040" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new acylamide ligand is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new acylamide ligand is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">During the past decade, the construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is the current interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, and more and more people have paid considerable attentions to research it, due to its extensive potential applications in catalysis, separation, ion-exchange, magnetism, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . Currently, several extreme interests on MOFs were focused on designing new topological architectures, and pioneers have disclosed many kinds of topological structure, such as NbO, PtS, CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> net, diamond net, rutile net, boracite net, sodalite net, etc.  Carefully checking the structure characters of MOFs, most of them were constructed from the single type of node, and the MOFs assembled from the double type of nodes are relatively less developed, such as the (3, 4) and (3, 6)-connected MOFs . To achieve this goal, the key factor is the choice of suitable organic ligands and metal centers; that is, to achieve the (3, 4)-connected net, one of the best ways is to choose metal centers with a low coordination number such as Zn, Cu, Co as 4-connected nodes and trigonal organic ligands as 3-connected nodes . Fortunately, herein, we report a novel MOF, namely [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)] [(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">·</ce:inf>DMF (Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dimethylamine cation, BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>,N<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bis (pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)), with (3, 4)-connected (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology and self-penetrating motif .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ A new acylamide ligand is reported.   ⋅ An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.   ⋅ A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.   

A new acylamide ligand is reported.

An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.

A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.

During the past decade, the construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is the current interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, and more and more people have paid considerable attentions to research it, due to its extensive potential applications in catalysis, separation, ion-exchange, magnetism, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . Currently, several extreme interests on MOFs were focused on designing new topological architectures, and pioneers have disclosed many kinds of topological structure, such as NbO, PtS, CdSO4 net, diamond net, rutile net, boracite net, sodalite net, etc.  Carefully checking the structure characters of MOFs, most of them were constructed from the single type of node, and the MOFs assembled from the double type of nodes are relatively less developed, such as the (3, 4) and (3, 6)-connected MOFs . To achieve this goal, the key factor is the choice of suitable organic ligands and metal centers; that is, to achieve the (3, 4)-connected net, one of the best ways is to choose metal centers with a low coordination number such as Zn, Cu, Co as 4-connected nodes and trigonal organic ligands as 3-connected nodes . Fortunately, herein, we report a novel MOF, namely [Zn2(BTC)2(L)] [(Me2NH2)2]⋅DMF (Me2NH2 =dimethylamine cation, BTC3- =1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L=N1,N4-bis (pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)), with (3, 4)-connected (6⋅82)(6⋅85)(62 ⋅10)(62 ⋅83 ⋅10) topology and self-penetrating motif .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this work, we selectively chose dipyridyl-amide ligands {[N<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>,N<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bis(pyridin-3-ylmethyl) cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)(L)} as organic linkers and polydentate O-donor H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) to construction of MOFs, based on the following considerations: (i) up to date, the L ligand has not been utilized to construct MOFs until this work; (ii) the ligand L possesses a flexible backbone containing bifunctional binding sites (both pyridyl groups), as well as a strong capacity for hydrogen bonding from amide groups, which is anticipated to play a vital role in the assembly of flexible MOFs;  (iii) deprotonation of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC can produce multiple products of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC, HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, and BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, with the number of potential donor oxygen atoms varying from one to six, are all versatile ligands for the construction of novel high-dimensional metal–organic hybrid compounds ; (iv) the high symmetry that it exhibits may be useful for the crystal growing of the product formed .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, we selectively chose dipyridyl-amide ligands {[N1,N4-bis(pyridin-3-ylmethyl) cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)(L)} as organic linkers and polydentate O-donor H3BTC (H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) to construction of MOFs, based on the following considerations: (i) up to date, the L ligand has not been utilized to construct MOFs until this work; (ii) the ligand L possesses a flexible backbone containing bifunctional binding sites (both pyridyl groups), as well as a strong capacity for hydrogen bonding from amide groups, which is anticipated to play a vital role in the assembly of flexible MOFs;  (iii) deprotonation of H3BTC can produce multiple products of H3BTC, HBTC2-, and BTC3-, with the number of potential donor oxygen atoms varying from one to six, are all versatile ligands for the construction of novel high-dimensional metal-organic hybrid compounds ; (iv) the high symmetry that it exhibits may be useful for the crystal growing of the product formed .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized with Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and the L ligand in DMF-water(3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL/1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution by solvo(hydro)thermal reaction at 115<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C . Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in <ce:italic>P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group . In this structure, the solvent molecules (DMF) and charge-balancing positive ions of [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> derived from the hydrolyzation of DMF are badly disordered and cannot be accurately determined, so they were squeezed by Platon Squeeze program . Thereafter, we use the ‘1-squeese.cif’ as the structure analysis data. The amount of them is estimated by EA and TG researches.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Polymer 1 was synthesized with Zn(NO3)2, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and the L ligand in DMF-water(3mL/1mL) solution by solvo(hydro)thermal reaction at 115°C . Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that polymer 1 crystallizes in P21 /c space group . In this structure, the solvent molecules (DMF) and charge-balancing positive ions of [Me2NH2]+ derived from the hydrolyzation of DMF are badly disordered and cannot be accurately determined, so they were squeezed by Platon Squeeze program . Thereafter, we use the ‘1-squeese.cif' as the structure analysis data. The amount of them is estimated by EA and TG researches.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, the asymmetric unit consists of two unique Zn(II) ions. Each zinc ion shows the four-coordinated ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N tetrahedral geometry completed by BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>oxygen atoms and L nitrogen atom. The coordination surrounding them is described in detail as follows. Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> is coordinated by O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, and O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>, from three BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> groups and N4 from L ligand; Zn2 is coordinated by O<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>, and O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> from three BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> groups and N<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> from the L ligand. The Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths range from 1.922<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to 2.015<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the bond lengths of Zn<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> are 2.014<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and 2.064<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, comparable with that reported in other Zn(II) compounds . For the BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand, it adopts the tri(monodentate) coordinated mode . On the other hand, the L ligand shows the bridging mode to link two zinc ions together.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , the asymmetric unit consists of two unique Zn(II) ions. Each zinc ion shows the four-coordinated ZnO3N tetrahedral geometry completed by BTC3-oxygen atoms and L nitrogen atom. The coordination surrounding them is described in detail as follows. Zn1 is coordinated by O3, O6, and O11, from three BTC3- groups and N4 from L ligand; Zn2 is coordinated by O1, O7, and O10 from three BTC3- groups and N1 from the L ligand. The ZnO bond lengths range from 1.922Å to 2.015Å, and the bond lengths of Zn1-N4 and Zn2-N1 are 2.014Å, and 2.064Å, respectively, comparable with that reported in other Zn(II) compounds . For the BTC3- ligand, it adopts the tri(monodentate) coordinated mode . On the other hand, the L ligand shows the bridging mode to link two zinc ions together.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the combination of zinc centers and BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> groups forms a 2D three-connecting bilayered structure. And further through L ligand, these 2D bilayers are integrated together to form a 3D layer-pillared net [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>]. Note that herein the L ligands not only act as pillars to support the 2D bilayered net, but also they are deeply embedded in the bilayered net, playing the penetrating role, thus resulting in the overall 3D self-penetrating net. Furthermore, the volume of void space (occupied by DMF and [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions) observed in polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is estimated by Platon program, giving 1684.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, equal to 33.0% of the cell volume, indicating potential porous framework of it .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , the combination of zinc centers and BTC3- groups forms a 2D three-connecting bilayered structure. And further through L ligand, these 2D bilayers are integrated together to form a 3D layer-pillared net [ ]. Note that herein the L ligands not only act as pillars to support the 2D bilayered net, but also they are deeply embedded in the bilayered net, playing the penetrating role, thus resulting in the overall 3D self-penetrating net. Furthermore, the volume of void space (occupied by DMF and [Me2NH2]+ ions) observed in polymer 1 is estimated by Platon program, giving 1684.5Å3, equal to 33.0% of the cell volume, indicating potential porous framework of it .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Topologically, if Zn(II) centers and the BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>units are viewed to be the 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>] and then this framework becomes a (3,4)-connected net with (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology built on four-connecting metal centers and three-connecting organic nodes. In the literature, there are a large number of (3, 4)-connected net such as Pt<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, jph, C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and twisted boracite net . In contrast to them, the present topology matrix is obviously different and holds self-penetrating motif that is still very rare in the literature. Moreover, the self-penetrating manner is described as catenations of the eight-membered circuits and ten-membered circuits [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Topologically, if Zn(II) centers and the BTC3-units are viewed to be the 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, [ ] and then this framework becomes a (3,4)-connected net with (6⋅82)(6⋅85)(62 ⋅10)(62 ⋅83 ⋅10) topology built on four-connecting metal centers and three-connecting organic nodes. In the literature, there are a large number of (3, 4)-connected net such as Pt3O4, jph, C3N4, and twisted boracite net . In contrast to them, the present topology matrix is obviously different and holds self-penetrating motif that is still very rare in the literature. Moreover, the self-penetrating manner is described as catenations of the eight-membered circuits and ten-membered circuits [ ].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">As show in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>, thermogravimetric analysis of the compound reveals that the weight loss (6.8%) in the temperature range of 20–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is derived from one DMF molecule (calc. 6.9%). And then there is no further weight loss until 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, after that temperature, the process of chemical decomposition was performed. In addition, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, an intense emission occurs at 409<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with the excitation wavelength at 322<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. As we know, the emission is mainly derived from the π–π* transition of organic ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As show in  , thermogravimetric analysis of the compound reveals that the weight loss (6.8%) in the temperature range of 20-200°C is derived from one DMF molecule (calc. 6.9%). And then there is no further weight loss until 400°C, after that temperature, the process of chemical decomposition was performed. In addition, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1 were measured. As shown in  , an intense emission occurs at 409nm with the excitation wavelength at 322nm. As we know, the emission is mainly derived from the π-π* transition of organic ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In conclusion, we successfully synthesized a new acylamide MOFs by solvo(hydro)thermal method. Interestingly, this polymer presents an unprecedented (3, 4)-connecting self-penetrating net with (6.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6.8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.10) topology. To some extent, the results will not only give us some guidance to generate L based MOFs that are scarce in the literature, but also enrich the database of topological net.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we successfully synthesized a new acylamide MOFs by solvo(hydro)thermal method. Interestingly, this polymer presents an unprecedented (3, 4)-connecting self-penetrating net with (6.82)(6.85)(62.10)(62.83.10) topology. To some extent, the results will not only give us some guidance to generate L based MOFs that are scarce in the literature, but also enrich the database of topological net.

</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0040">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref id="ir0005" xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">
<ce:italic>Synthesis of polymer 1</ce:italic>: Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC(0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and L ligand(0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were sealed in a Teflon reactor with 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and heated at 115<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>day, and then cooled to room temperature at 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, and colorless crystal was obtained in the yield of 79%, based on Zn. EA analysis (%): calc. C/50.86, N/9.23,H/5.03; exp. C/50.97, N/9.34, H/5.12. (All regents are analytically pure, and water is distilled water).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

      

Supplementary material

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034.

 Synthesis of polymer 1: Zn(NO3)2 (0.2mmol), H3BTC(0.2mmol) and L ligand(0.1mmol) were sealed in a Teflon reactor with 3mL DMF and 1mL H2O, and heated at 115°C for 2day, and then cooled to room temperature at 3°C/h, and colorless crystal was obtained in the yield of 79%, based on Zn. EA analysis (%): calc. C/50.86, N/9.23,H/5.03; exp. C/50.97, N/9.34, H/5.12. (All regents are analytically pure, and water is distilled water).

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Single-crystal diffraction intensity data were collected on Bruker Smart Breeze CCD with MoKα radiation (0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the measurement method is phi and omega scans, and corrected with SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL program . Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18.4146(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.8807(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17.4536(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>91.322(2)°<ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5102.7(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, <ce:italic>GOF</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.972, all data final <ce:italic>R1</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0647, <ce:italic>ωR2</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1120.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal diffraction intensity data were collected on Bruker Smart Breeze CCD with MoKα radiation (0.71073Å) at 298K, the measurement method is phi and omega scans, and corrected with SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL program . Crystal data for 1: monoclinic, space group P21 /c, a =18.4146(6)Å, b =15.8807(5)Å, c =17.4536(5)Å, β =91.322(2)°V =5102.7(3)Å3, Z=4, GOF =0.972, all data final R1 =0.0647, ωR2 =0.1120.

Supplementary material

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034.

 Synthesis of polymer 1: Zn(NO3)2 (0.2mmol), H3BTC(0.2mmol) and L ligand(0.1mmol) were sealed in a Teflon reactor with 3mL DMF and 1mL H2O, and heated at 115°C for 2day, and then cooled to room temperature at 3°C/h, and colorless crystal was obtained in the yield of 79%, based on Zn. EA analysis (%): calc. C/50.86, N/9.23,H/5.03; exp. C/50.97, N/9.34, H/5.12. (All regents are analytically pure, and water is distilled water).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the combination of zinc centers and BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> groups forms a 2D three-connecting bilayered structure. And further through L ligand, these 2D bilayers are integrated together to form a 3D layer-pillared net [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>]. Note that herein the L ligands not only act as pillars to support the 2D bilayered net, but also they are deeply embedded in the bilayered net, playing the penetrating role, thus resulting in the overall 3D self-penetrating net. Furthermore, the volume of void space (occupied by DMF and [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions) observed in polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is estimated by Platon program, giving 1684.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, equal to 33.0% of the cell volume, indicating potential porous framework of it .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">As show in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>, thermogravimetric analysis of the compound reveals that the weight loss (6.8%) in the temperature range of 20–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is derived from one DMF molecule (calc. 6.9%). And then there is no further weight loss until 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, after that temperature, the process of chemical decomposition was performed. In addition, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, an intense emission occurs at 409<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with the excitation wavelength at 322<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. As we know, the emission is mainly derived from the π–π* transition of organic ligands.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Single-crystal diffraction intensity data were collected on Bruker Smart Breeze CCD with MoKα radiation (0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the measurement method is phi and omega scans, and corrected with SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL program . Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18.4146(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.8807(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17.4536(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>91.322(2)°<ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5102.7(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, <ce:italic>GOF</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.972, all data final <ce:italic>R1</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0647, <ce:italic>ωR2</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1120.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
As shown in  , the combination of zinc centers and BTC3- groups forms a 2D three-connecting bilayered structure. And further through L ligand, these 2D bilayers are integrated together to form a 3D layer-pillared net [ ]. Note that herein the L ligands not only act as pillars to support the 2D bilayered net, but also they are deeply embedded in the bilayered net, playing the penetrating role, thus resulting in the overall 3D self-penetrating net. Furthermore, the volume of void space (occupied by DMF and [Me2NH2]+ ions) observed in polymer 1 is estimated by Platon program, giving 1684.5Å3, equal to 33.0% of the cell volume, indicating potential porous framework of it .

As show in  , thermogravimetric analysis of the compound reveals that the weight loss (6.8%) in the temperature range of 20-200°C is derived from one DMF molecule (calc. 6.9%). And then there is no further weight loss until 400°C, after that temperature, the process of chemical decomposition was performed. In addition, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1 were measured. As shown in  , an intense emission occurs at 409nm with the excitation wavelength at 322nm. As we know, the emission is mainly derived from the π-π* transition of organic ligands.

Single-crystal diffraction intensity data were collected on Bruker Smart Breeze CCD with MoKα radiation (0.71073Å) at 298K, the measurement method is phi and omega scans, and corrected with SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL program . Crystal data for 1: monoclinic, space group P21 /c, a =18.4146(6)Å, b =15.8807(5)Å, c =17.4536(5)Å, β =91.322(2)°V =5102.7(3)Å3, Z=4, GOF =0.972, all data final R1 =0.0647, ωR2 =0.1120.
